children.subject: this is how it worked before with telebears, i don't know about the reasons for why the system changed but the transition from telebears to calcentral for enrollment brought this side effect :/

history.content:
The department does not assign enrollment times. This change was an intentional campus-wide decision.

Your idea would give benefit to students who were able to take AP, IB, or community college courses in high school. This is not available to everyone, given different offerings at different high schools (often related to the socioeconomic class of the community served by the school), and other obligations (such as working). It would also give undue benefit to students who are able to take many units per semester, as compared to those required to work, care for family, commute, etc while in school.

While graduating early may be an option to you, you are not entitled to it at the detriment of other students.

The department does not assign enrollment times. This was an intentional campus-wide decision.

Your idea would give benefit to students who were able to take AP, IB, or community college courses in high school. This is not available to everyone, given different offerings at different high school, and other obligations (such as working). It would also give undue benefit to students who are able to take many units per semester, as compared to those required to work, care for family, commute, etc while in school.

children.subject:
The nature of enrollment time assignment inherently disallows the ability to be completely "fair" in the sense that certain people will have to live with the fact that they have later enrollment assignments than do others. As someone who came into Berkeley with sophomore standing and is graduating a semester early, I agree that at times I thought it was a bit of an inconvenience that my academic standing + early graduation status didn't factor into my enrollment assignment. However, ultimately I realized that I would gladly take that inconvenience if it meant that my peers who were not fortunate enough to have advanced units or the ability to take as many units while at Berkeley due to having to work to afford to attend school would be able to have the same chance to get into classes as I did.

Essentially, while it may seem unfair to you that you worked so hard to achieve the advanced academic standing that you have achieved (and kudos to you for doing so), understand that some of your classmates simply did not have the option to do so because of factors outside of their control, and the university decided that this inability should not further set them back by assigning them later time slots than their more fortunate peers, such as yourself, were given.
To instructor: I understand you concern, but is it fair for people to have no chance to get into classes because they are at a lower standing, not based on their actual progress?

shoulda been a regent's scholar if you wanted preferred enrollment over the people you got admitted with :) otherwise you're just disadvantaging students from different backgrounds by doing this. enough aspects of the University work to enforce preexisting socioeconomic disparities between admitted students (i.e. gpa cap for majors which STRONGLY puts people who had exposure to that subject at an advantage), so let's do our best to recognize and work against those things instead of just trying to get in and out of here asap

history.content:
Hi, I would like to suggest a potential improvement in assigning enrollment time.

As we can see, many lower divs classes and must-take upper divs (like 170) have very high enrollment capacity, however, there are also some classes that runs out of seat even before a junior or sophomore Phase 1 starts. However, some of us are planning to graduate early, some may want to take certain classes for research. In many cases, we have already taken large must-takes and have to choose a more specialized classes. Every student have an "Academic Standing" on their calcentral (which is calculated by units instead of actual standing), I think department could consider that when assigning enrollment time so that those who has taken a lot of units and want to graduate early could also have access to interesting classes like CS182.  

I agree with instructor response that it will benefit "students who were able to take AP, IB, or community college courses in high school", so lets say let's exclude those exam credits and look at people's units at Berkeley and their progress in fulfilling the pre-reqs, is this possible?
history.subject: Suggestion: Consider academic standing on Calcentral when assigning enrollment time
